required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of OrthoviscÂ® to Corticosteroid Injection in Shoulder Osteoarthritis: Orthovisc Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: A comparison of Orthovisc to corticosteroid injections in the shoulder for pain due to osteoarthritis.

detailed_description.textblock: This multicenter, prospective double-blinded, randomized trial will study two treatment groups. Subjects will be randomized to receive either Orthovisc or corticosteroids/anesthetic injection into the shoulder in a 2:1 schema. The trial will assess safety and efficacy of pain relief in the osteoarthritic shoulder.

primary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
primary_outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
primary_outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
secondary_outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
secondary_outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in pain was calculated as visit score - baseline score. Scores are measured on a 100 mm visual analogy scale.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (As Treated)
secondary_outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. The difference in pain was calculated as visit score - baseline score.

secondary_outcome.measure: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The ASES was designed to provide a standard method for evaluation of the shoulder through assessment of pain and activities of daily living (ie, function). The ASES is derived from an equation that incorporates a visual analog pain scale and functional ability questions. Both components have a maximum score of 50. Pain is calculated by subtracting the visual analog score from 10 and then multiplying by 5 for a total of 50 points. The function component is calculated by adding the points and multiplying by five thirds for a maximum of 50 points. The subscores for pain and function are then added for the total score. The maximum possible total score is 100, representing less pain and greater function.

secondary_outcome.measure: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (As Treated)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The ASES was designed to provide a standard method for evaluation of the shoulder through assessment of pain and activities of daily living (ie, function). The ASES is derived from an equation that incorporates a visual analog pain scale and functional ability questions. Both components have a maximum score of 50. Pain is calculated by subtracting the visual analog score from 10 and then multiplying by 5 for a total of 50 points. The function component is calculated by adding the points and multiplying by five thirds for a maximum of 50 points. The subscores for pain and function are then added for the total score. The maximum possible total score is 100, representing less pain and greater function.

secondary_outcome.description: The difference in American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient score calculated as visit score - baseline score. secondary_outcome.measure: Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of two dimensions, one for pain and the other for functional activities. The pain dimension consists of five questions regarding the severity of an individual's pain, where: 0 = no pain and 10 = the worst pain imaginable. Functional activities are assessed with eight questions designed to measure the degree of difficulty an individual has with various activities of daily living that require upper-extremity use, where: 0 = no difficulty and 10 = so difficult it requires help. Scoring instructions: The scores from both dimensions are averaged to derive a total score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (As Treated)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability score calculated as visit score - baseline score. secondary_outcome.measure: 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Physical Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Physical score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The SF-12 is a generic measure and does not target a specific age or disease group. It has been developed to provide a shorter, yet valid alternative to the SF-36, which has been seen by many health researchers as too long to administer to studies with large samples. The SF-12 is weighted and summed to provide easily interpretable scales for physical and mental health. Physical and Mental Health Composite Scores (PCS & MCS) are computed using the scores of twelve questions and range from 0 to 100, where a zero score indicates the lowest level of health measured by the scales and 100 indicates the highest level of health.

arm_group.description: Subjects randomized to the control arm injection of prescribed anesthetic and corticosteroid, shall receive an equivalent volume (8 mL's).
Subjects randomized to the active treatment in this study will receive a one-time dose of 8 mL's of Orthovisc derived from non-animal source bacterial fermentation, S. Equi.

intervention.description: Celestone (betamethasone sodium phosphate and acetate) - 2 mL

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- A candidate for unilateral treatment of osteoarthritis of the shoulder
- Have failed conservative treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of full thickness Rotator Cuff tear and/or significantly compromised rotator cuff function
- No active instability or acute dislocation episodes within the previous 12 months
- Known allergy to hyaluronate preparations
- Pregnant or breast feeding
- Is receiving prescription pain medication for conditions unrelated to the index shoulder condition

facility.name: Sierra Pacific Orthopaedic Center Medical Group
University of Massachusetts Merdical School - Worcester

patient_data.ipd_description: We will not submit the data to FDA, and as such will not be making IPD available.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Enrollment occurred between January 2007 and February 2010 at 13 sites based in the US.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Four subjects were randomized; however due to required imaging inclusion/exclusion criteria was not met. Hence, these 4 subjects were not treated.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

baseline.population: The number of partipants analyzed were all 270 subjects that received treatment (87 control, 183 investigational).

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
Age, Customized
Sex: Female, Male
Region of Enrollment

outcome.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
measure.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.
measure.units: mm on a 100 mm VAS scale

analysis.groups_desc: Anticipated VAS difference of 10 mm and SD of 25 mm indicated a sample size of 225 subjects in a 2:1 randomization would provide 80% power to detect a significant difference with a two-sided significance level of 5%. To account for a 15% dropout rate the sample size was increased to 270 subjects (180 Orthovisc, 90 control). The primary null hypothesis (Ho) no difference in VAS means at 6 months and the alternative hypothesis (Ha) was that Orthovisc (mean VAS) is superior to the control.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (Per Protocol)
measure.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

analysis.groups_desc: Asymptotic 95% confidence interval for the treatment group difference (Orthovisc - Control) in proportions of responders was calculated. The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is equal and the corresponding alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is unequal.

outcome.title: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.
outcome.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Percentage of Responders Using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
measure.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain. A responder was defined as a 20 mm or greater reduction in VAS pain score from baseline to 6 months.
measure.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.

analysis.groups_desc: Asymptotic 95% confidence interval for the treatment group difference (Orthovisc - Control) in proportions of responders was calculated. The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is equal and the corresponding alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is unequal.

outcome.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: The difference in pain was calculated as visit score - baseline score. Scores are measured on a 100 mm visual analogy scale.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation. Subjects were allowed to have missing interim visits (i.e. 12 weeks).

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
measure.description: The difference in pain was calculated as visit score - baseline score. Scores are measured on a 100 mm visual analogy scale.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation. Subjects were allowed to have missing interim visits (i.e. 12 weeks).
measure.units: mm on a 100 mm VAS scale

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 12 weeks is equal and the corresponding alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups is unequal.
analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value was not adjusted for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.

outcome.title: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient Score Change From Baseline and 6 Months (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: The difference in American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The ASES was designed to provide a standard method for evaluation of the shoulder through assessment of pain and activities of daily living (ie, function). The ASES is derived from an equation that incorporates a visual analog pain scale and functional ability questions. Both components have a maximum score of 50. Pain is calculated by subtracting the visual analog score from 10 and then multiplying by 5 for a total of 50 points. The function component is calculated by adding the points and multiplying by five thirds for a maximum of 50 points. The subscores for pain and function are then added for the total score. The maximum possible total score is 100, representing less pain and greater function.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient Score Change From Baseline and 6 Months (Per Protocol)
measure.description: The difference in American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Evaluation Form (ASES) Patient score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The ASES was designed to provide a standard method for evaluation of the shoulder through assessment of pain and activities of daily living (ie, function). The ASES is derived from an equation that incorporates a visual analog pain scale and functional ability questions. Both components have a maximum score of 50. Pain is calculated by subtracting the visual analog score from 10 and then multiplying by 5 for a total of 50 points. The function component is calculated by adding the points and multiplying by five thirds for a maximum of 50 points. The subscores for pain and function are then added for the total score. The maximum possible total score is 100, representing less pain and greater function.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is equal and the corresponding alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups is unequal.
analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value was not adjusted for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.title: Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: The difference in Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of two dimensions, one for pain and the other for functional activities. The pain dimension consists of five questions regarding the severity of an individual's pain, where: 0 = no pain and 10 = the worst pain imaginable. Functional activities are assessed with eight questions designed to measure the degree of difficulty an individual has with various activities of daily living that require upper-extremity use, where: 0 = no difficulty and 10 = so difficult it requires help. Scoring instructions: The scores from both dimensions are averaged to derive a total score.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation. Subjects were allowed to have missing interim visits (i.e. 12 weeks).

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
measure.description: The difference in Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) Total Disability score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of two dimensions, one for pain and the other for functional activities. The pain dimension consists of five questions regarding the severity of an individual's pain, where: 0 = no pain and 10 = the worst pain imaginable. Functional activities are assessed with eight questions designed to measure the degree of difficulty an individual has with various activities of daily living that require upper-extremity use, where: 0 = no difficulty and 10 = so difficult it requires help. Scoring instructions: The scores from both dimensions are averaged to derive a total score.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation. Subjects were allowed to have missing interim visits (i.e. 12 weeks).

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 12 weeks is equal and the corresponding alternative (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is unequal.
analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value was not adjusted for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
outcome.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.
outcome.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (As Treated)
measure.description: Scores are measured on a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The VAS scale ranges from 0 to 100 mm with the lower score indicating less pain and the higher score indicating greater pain.
measure.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.
measure.units: mm on a 100 mm VAS scale

analysis.groups_desc: Anticipated VAS difference of 10 mm and SD of 25 mm indicated a sample size of 225 subjects in a 2:1 randomization would provide 80% power to detect a significant difference with a two-sided significance level of 5%. To account for a 15% dropout rate the sample size was increased to 270 subjects (180 Orthovisc, 90 control). The primary null hypothesis (Ho) no difference in VAS means at 6 months and the alternative hypothesis (Ha) was that Orthovisc (mean VAS) is superior to the control.
analysis.p_value_desc: The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.title: 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Physical Score Change From Baseline and 12 Weeks (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: The difference in 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Physical score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The SF-12 is a generic measure and does not target a specific age or disease group. It has been developed to provide a shorter, yet valid alternative to the SF-36, which has been seen by many health researchers as too long to administer to studies with large samples. The SF-12 is weighted and summed to provide easily interpretable scales for physical and mental health. Physical and Mental Health Composite Scores (PCS & MCS) are computed using the scores of twelve questions and range from 0 to 100, where a zero score indicates the lowest level of health measured by the scales and 100 indicates the highest level of health.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation. Subjects were allowed to have missing interim visits (i.e. 12 weeks).

measure.description: The difference in 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Mental score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The SF-12 is a generic measure and does not target a specific age or disease group. It has been developed to provide a shorter, yet valid alternative to the SF-36, which has been seen by many health researchers as too long to administer to studies with large samples. The SF-12 is weighted and summed to provide easily interpretable scales for physical and mental health. Physical and Mental Health Composite Scores (PCS & MCS) are computed using the scores of twelve questions and range from 0 to 100, where a zero score indicates the lowest level of health measured by the scales and 100 indicates the highest level of health.
measure.population: The As Treated analysis population included all subjects that received treatment and had outcome data.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 12 weeks is equal and the corresponding alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups is unequal.
analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value was not adjusted for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

outcome.title: 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Mental Score Change From Baseline and 6 Months (Per Protocol)
outcome.description: The difference in 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Mental score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The SF-12 is a generic measure and does not target a specific age or disease group. It has been developed to provide a shorter, yet valid alternative to the SF-36, which has been seen by many health researchers as too long to administer to studies with large samples. The SF-12 is weighted and summed to provide easily interpretable scales for physical and mental health. Physical and Mental Health Composite Scores (PCS & MCS) are computed using the scores of twelve questions and range from 0 to 100, where a zero score indicates the lowest level of health measured by the scales and 100 indicates the highest level of health.
outcome.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine) and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

measure.title: 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Mental Score Change From Baseline and 6 Months (Per Protocol)
measure.description: The difference in 12-Item Short Form Survey (SF-12) Mental score calculated as visit score - baseline score. The SF-12 is a generic measure and does not target a specific age or disease group. Physical and Mental Health Composite Scores (PCS & MCS) are computed using the scores of twelve questions and range from 0 to 100, where a zero score indicates the lowest level of health measured by the scales and 100 indicates the highest level of health.
measure.population: The Per Protocol analysis population was defined as all subjects that received treatment and completed 6 months of follow-up without a major protocol deviation.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis (Ho) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is equal and the corresponding alternative (Ha) is that the effect of the two treatment groups at 6 months is unequal.
analysis.p_value_desc: The p-value was not adjusted for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold for significance was a two-sided p <0.05.
analysis.method_desc: The analysis included baseline score as a covariate. Site was dropped from the model due to statistical insignificance.

reported_events.time_frame: The first subject was randomized and treated in January, 2007. The last subject completed the study in August, 2010. Total timeframe: 3 years, 7 months
reported_events.desc: All subjects that received study treatment are included in the safety population.

group.title: Control
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection containing 6 mL of anesthetic (Marcaine)and 2 mL of corticosteroid (Celestone).

group.title: Investigational
group.description: Each subject received a one-time injection of 8 mL's of Orthovisc into the target shoulder.

Open Heart Surgery After Aortic Valve Disease
Left Shoulder Pain Non-Study Shoulder - Surgery 6/10/09

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Patient has cancer, did not specify to PI where cancer is, never returned, lost to follow-up
Total Shoulder Arthroplasty Plus Bone Graft Glenoid Scapular Right Shoulder

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
